author: COMSOL
description:
The transmission speed of optical waveguides is superior to microwave waveguides because optical devices have a much higher operating frequency than microwaves, enabling a far higher bandwidth. Single-mode step-index fibers are used for long-haul (even transoceanic) communication, whereas both graded-index (GRIN) and step-index multimode fibers are used for short-distance communication, for example, within institutions and university campuses and buildings.

For almost all commercial optical fiber types, the design consists of a concentric layer structure with the inner layer(s) forming the core and the outer layer(s) forming the cladding. Since the core has a higher refractive index than the cladding, guided modes can propagate along the fiber.
label: fiber_simulator.mph
name: root

textmulti
settings.value:
Each layer is described by an outer diameter and the real and imaginary parts of the refractive index. The refractive index expressions can include a wavelength dependence, by including the parameter lda0, and a dependence on the radial coordinate, by including the variable r.

To distinguish the different layers in plots, for instance the refractive index plots, different names can be assign to the layers.

settings.name: tooltip
settings.value: Click to close this help dialog

settings.name: tooltip
settings.value: Click to get help on how the available materials can be used

settings.name: textmulti
settings.value: In expressions for the real and the imaginary part of the refractive index, refer to the functions for the real and the imaginary parts of the refractive index using the material tag. I.e use "mat3.n(lda0)" to refer to the real part of the  refractive index for SiO2 (Malitson) and similarly "mat3.ki(lda0)" to refer to the imaginary part of the refractive index for the same material.
